Farha ⁎ Department of Chemistry and International Institute of Nanotechnology, Northwestern University, 2145 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL 60208, United States Department of Chemistry and International Institute of Nanotechnology Northwestern University 2145 Sheridan Road Evanston IL 60208 United States Department of Chemistry and International Institute of Nanotechnology, Northwestern University, 2145 Sheridan Road, Evanston, Illinois 60208, United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Heterogeneous catalysts streamline industrial processes due to high stability and ease of separation. Efforts toward predictive catalytic activity and rational design of next-generation systems are impeded by structural ambiguity stemming from the presence of multiple irregular active sites within a catalyst. The uniformity of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) provides a platform on which to develop single site catalysts in order to delineate atomically precise design rules. In this critical review, we highlight the development and progress of MOF-based single site catalysts and provide an outlook for further advancement of the field. Keywords Metal–organic frameworks Heterogeneous catalysis Single site 1 Introduction Concerns regarding the sustainability of the global population and planet have necessitated the development of efficient catalytic processes to produce value-added commodities. Predicting and developing catalysts with high activity have been well documented with homogenous catalysts owing to their discrete and well-defined nature. However, the difficulty of separation, deactivation pathways, and thermal instability of soluble catalyst often impede on their implementation in industrial settings [1]. Instead, the installation of active sites onto robust and recyclable solid supports has rendered heterogeneous catalysts ubiquitous in demanding processes, such as Haber-Bosch, Fischer-Tropsch, and petroleum refining [2]. By discretely isolating and anchoring active site(s) like metal complexes or nanoparticles, heterogeneous supports give rise to favorable confinement effects and prevent catalyst deactivation through nocent self-association, permitting enhanced reactivity compared to their homogeneous counterparts [3,4]. Reducing the size of the anchored metal species is desirable due to an inherent increase in unsaturated coordination bonds, leading to greater number of possible active sites [5,6]. Single-ion catalysts (SIC) have been long referred to as isolated metal sites singly dispersed on supports [7]. Such a category of catalysts are highly sought after to eliminate “wasted” metal species such that all deposited metal species are accessible and can interact with a reagent [8,9]. Despite their monometallic nature, SICs can possess nonuniformity from the ill-defined supports to which they are anchored [10]. In recent years, the term single-site heterogeneous catalyst (SSHC) has appeared, often deriving some confusion with SIC. A SSHC may, or may not, be monometallic, while a SIC must be a singly dispersed atomic-level species (Fig. 1 ). The distinguishing feature of a SSHC is that each catalytically active species is completely identical, which can be accomplished via anchoring to a highly uniform, periodic structure. Best described by Thomas et al., a SSHC features “no spectroscopic or other cross-talk between such sites. Each site has the same energy of interaction between it and a reactant as every other single site; and each such site is structurally well-characterized” [10]. Ideally such characterization is achieved with atomically precise techniques like single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Confidence in the refinement of the single site on a MOF requires immense care due to inherent disorder often prevalent in MOF diffraction data, as recently highlighted by Lillerud and co-workers [11]. Therefore, other characterization methods should be utilized in tandem with crystallography to both support the identity of a single site and probe the uniformity of all catalyst sites. SICs represent the most efficient arrangement of a species to maximize the metal loading for a reaction, but the uniform active sites present in SSHC are advantageous for delineating structure-activity relationships. Metal oxides, serving as traditional heterogeneous supports, can exhibit facets and anchoring sites with vastly different surface energies [12–14] and deviate from an ideal structure. To achieve the structural homogeneity required by SSHCs, a uniform platform is required instead. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), an emerging class of highly porous, well-defined crystalline materials, have attracted considerable interest for catalysis, gas storage/separation, and chemical sensing, among other applications [15–19]. These materials are composed of inorganic nodes and multidentate organic linkers that assemble into multidimensional lattices through coordination bonds (Fig. 2 A) [20–23]. Available nodes and linkers access a seemingly infinite number of framework connectivities and offer precise control of chemical functionality. MOF periodicity eliminates the structural variability present in traditional solid-phase supports, providing a platform to delineate structure-property relationships [24]. The synthetic versatility and robustness of the frameworks have made MOFs attractive scaffolds for high-preforming catalysts in recent years, and this field has been well-reviewed and studied [15,25–41]. However, a defining feature of MOF catalysts is the ability to isolate periodic active sites without variability in the system to elucidate useful mechanistic insights. Herein, we provide an overview of SSHCs within MOFs to highlight recent progress in the field and to reinforce guidelines on defining SSHCs. We will examine recent SSHCs in MOFs that are present at the nodes, linkers, and pores (Fig. 2B). SSHCs can exist at the node through open metal sites or metal deposition through well-established postsynthetic techniques. Judicious linker design imparts catalytic activity with reactive functionalities either at the linker itself or through postsynthetic modifications. Recent work with the incorporation of active sites in MOFs through the encapsulation of typically homogeneous species including transition-metal complexes, enzymes, and discrete polyoxometalates is lastly discussed. Although well studied and developed, the incorporation of nanoparticles to MOF cavities [34,42–47] and MOF-based electrocatalysts [48–52] will not be discussed in this review, but the reader can be informed with the provided reviews and work. Several examples of photocatalytic MOF SSHCs will be highlighted herein, but other impressive works have been previously reviewed [53–57]. 2 Catalysis at metal nodes The spatial arrangement of distinct metal nodes allows for the installation of single sites in MOFs through the exposition of unsaturated metal sites, the deposition of active metal sites, or the efficient transmetalation of de novo metals in the node. One way of including metals with available coordination sites is by creating missing linker or missing node defects, which are commonly observed and modulated within some of the well-studied MOFs such as the UiO series [22,58]. These defective sites render the material highly catalytically active and therefore, many procedures have been optimized to afford the wide distribution of such sites. Discussion of catalysis at these defective sites within MOFs is omitted from this review because active sites at such defects eliminate the periodic nature of a MOF. However, the intentional design of defective sites for catalysis has been widely studied [59–62]. 2.1 Catalysis at open metal sites on nodes An open metal site (OMS), also referred to as a coordinately unsaturated site (CUS), describes an unsaturated metal coordination environment which in some instances can afford a highly reactive species. Owing to such reactivity, OMSs are difficult to isolate as discrete complexes in solution to identify their precise structure and implement as catalytic species. The rigidity of a three-dimensional coordination bond network isolates and stabilizes unsaturated coordination environments. Postsynthetic techniques enable the removal of remaining labile solvents or other guest species to access OMSs. For example, the dehydration of terminal water groups on Cu2(ATC) (ATC = 1,3,5,7-adamantane tetracarboxylate) was employed to identify the first OMS in a MOF through single crystal studies [63]. Such formative work prompted the continued characterization and utilization of OMSs in MOFs such as the well-established frameworks MOF-74, HKUST-1, and the MIL series [64–67]. In their report of MIL-100(Fe), Férey and coworkers characterized an OMS-containing trimer of FeIII carboxylate octahedra that coordinates to tritopic benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate linkers to assemble as a supertetrahedron (Fig. 3 A) [68]. MIL-100(Fe) outperformed its isostructural Cr analogue as well as two solid acid-based zeolites in the liquid phase benzylation of benzene by benzyl chloride (Fig. 3B). The authors attributed the high redox activity of FeIII as a critical component for activating the reagents; the low propensity of CrIII to form CrII and subsequent poor performance of MIL-100(Cr) support this hypothesis. Other reports of oxidation reactions utilizing MIL-100(Fe) confirm the MOF’s high redox activity [69,70]; however, the robust nature of the framework inspired more application driven investigations. Recently, MIL-100(Fe) was used as an efficient catalyst for the conversion of ozone to oxygen and successfully incorporated into films and cloth mask filers to reduce ground-level ozone contamination [71]. Remarkable efficiency was observed for the MOF with 100% ozone conversion after 100 continuous hours under 45% relative humidity (RH) at room temperature (RT), outperforming highly porous activated carbon and metal oxides including Fe2O3 (Fig. 4 ). High ozone conversion observed in the Fe-based framework suggests that the FeIII state in addition to high porosity and large apertures within MIL-100(Fe) synergistically enables such efficacy. Interestingly, the MIL-100(Fe) framework performed better under high humidity environments, achieving full conversion from 40% to 90% RH, in stark contrast to other ozone decomposition catalysts that typically worsen in performance in the presence of water. These conditions mimic a variety of possible atmospheric environments on the planet, and so this catalyst has the potential for wide-spread implementation. The authors proposed that the presence of water could be favorable for a peroxide intermediate or higher valent iron species that facilitates reaction turnover. Further studies are needed to better elucidate the role of water in this efficient transformation. OMSs within zirconium-based MOFs have been used for the catalytic degradation of phosphate based chemical warfare agents and dimethyl 4-nitrophenyl phosphate (DMNP), a less toxic chemical possessing target agent functionalities known as a simulant [72–80]. The active site of the Zr-OH-Zr node resembles the Lewis acidic active site of Zn-OH-Zn in phosphotriesterase, the enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing organophosphorus substrates. The 8-connected Zr-based MOF, NU-1000, (Fig. 5 A) is effective for the conversion of DMNP with a half-life of 15 min at pH 10 (Fig. 5B). The impressive performance of NU-1000 can be attributed to the high accessibility of the Lewis acidic Zr sites with a unique 8-connected node and rapid substrate diffusion through the mesoporous channels. Terminal water ligands on the Zr6 node are replaced by the agent to yield an active site. The permanent porosity and site isolation were found to be critical for the performance of NU-1000 as a catalyst since the solution species of Zr6 clusters or Zr salts performed poorly under the same reaction conditions. Simulations of nerve agents GD and VX interacting with the active Zr node suggest an energetically more favorable hydrolysis of the PF bond and PS bond respectively as compared to the PO bond in DMNP [72]. Such promising data prompted the hydrolysis of GD with NU-1000 which achieved a half-life of 3 min under optimized reaction conditions. Even at 50% RH, NU-1000 exhibited remarkable performance, rendering NU-1000 as one of the top preforming solid catalysts for GD hydrolysis. Tuning the accessibility of the Zr active site can be accomplished through varying the connectivity of the Zr6 node and consequently changing the number of terminal aqua ligands present, which are replaced by the agent to form an active site (Fig. 6 ). [73,80,81]. In general, the lower connected MOFs, like MOF-808 and NU-1400 (6- and 4-connected respectively), performed the hydrolysis reaction at faster rates than higher connected MOFs like UiO-66 (12-connected). The impressive work by Yaghi’s group recently provided atomic level insights into the strong Brønsted acid site present in MOF-808-SO4 that are indeterminate in highly-used solid acids, such as sulfated zirconia, with highly variable surfaces [82]. Single crystal analyses of MOF-808-SO4 indicate a synergistic relationship between the chelating sulfate moiety and the adjacent terminal water ligand on the MOF to afford the high Brønsted acidity on the surface of the Zr clusters. To quantify the acidic sites, deprotonation energies were extrapolated from monitoring the adsorption of trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) onto MOF-808-SO4 with solid state NMR. Such studies indicated the material’s behavior is comparable to a superacid. MOF-808-SO4 outperformed commercial catalysts including sulfated zirconia, H-ZSM-5, and Amberlyst in the conversion of isobutene to C8 products. The poor catalytic activity of dehydrated MOF-808-SO4 suggests such Brønsted acidity on the node cannot be achieved in the absence of water, in agreement with previously generated single crystal structures and DFT optimizations (Fig. 7 ). 2.2 Catalysis at the node via metal deposition Postsynthetic deposition of metal species onto accessible Lewis basic species, such as OH2 and OH groups on MOF nodes, directs the complexation to achieve SSHCs throughout the bulk framework. We will focus on work that utilizes the crystallinity of MOFs to garner precise, atomic level details regarding catalyst behavior. Zhou and coworkers detailed the deposition of NiII, CoII, and InIII onto the Zr-based MOF PCN-700 with 8-connected bcu net and monitored the single crystal to single crystal transformation resulting from the Ni and Co loading [83]. The 8-connected framework features structural flexibility that gives rise to a topologically distinct phase, denoted PCN-800(M), where M = Ni, Co, or In. This phase change was proposed to occur from a ligand migration through protonation of terminal OH2 and μ3-OH groups. The decrease in the torsion angle of the linker from PCN-700 to PCN-800(Ni) by 13° indicates the coordination environment of a postsynthetically deposited metal species prompted a change in the ligand conformation (Fig. 8 ). Isostructural PCN-800(In) was employed to carry out an efficient acetaldehyde cyclotrimerization to paraldehyde which achieved 76% conversion and ˜99% selectivity within 2 h at RT, nearly identical to the activity of homogeneous InCl3. Even at elevated temperature, bare PCN-700 reported negligible activity. A vanadium catalyst was installed by our team onto the nodes of Hf-MOF-808 for selective alcohol oxidation [84]. Crystallographic data revealed the Hf framework contain three distinct V sites (Fig. 9 A). Under the reaction conditions, however, the activity of Hf-MOF-808-V for alcohol oxidation (Fig. 9B) increased as the reaction progressed (Fig. 9C). To probe this observation, single crystals of the catalyst were heated overnight in identical conditions to the oxidation reaction, and the catalyst structures were reexamined. According to single crystal analyses, Hf-MOF-808-V shifts from a single ion-based catalyst with multiple V catalyst motifs on the node to one crystallographically unique single site. Through the course of the initial reaction, the catalyst evolved with time to a more active form which increased the turnover frequency (TOF). Experimental evidence supported this hypothesis by heating the catalyst under vacuum and preventing rehydration of the catalyst prior to the reaction. Such treatment favored the active V motif on the node which resulted in a turnover frequency (TOF) three times greater than the catalyst without prior thermal treatment. High performance Ni complexes for the hydrogenolysis of aryl ethers motivated Lin and team to isolate a Ni-based SSHC to probe the catalytic activity of the species [85,86]. NiII was deposited onto the Ti8 node of MIL-125 to form TiIV 8-BDC-NiBr as observed through single crystal analysis (Fig. 10 ). An in situ reduction of the framework was performed which reduced TiIV rather than NiII as suggested by X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), forming TiIII 2TiIV 6-BDC-NiH. The mixed valent framework cleaved aryl ethers and formed aromatic compounds under mild conditions (Fig. 10). Minimal catalytic activity was found when reactions were catalyzed with Ni nanoparticles, precluding their role as active catalytic species that could have evolved during the reduction of the framework. Moreover, fully tetravalent Ti-BDC-NiBr and Ti-BDC-NiH display no catalytic activity. The authors proposed that mixed Ti valency on the nodes is critical for the activation of H2 due to increased electron density on NiII centers. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that the rate-determining step is σ-bond metathesis between [Ni]OPh to form [Ni]H and phenol. Simulations of oxidative addition and reductive elimination pathways revealed unlikely intermediate species and high energy barriers, further supporting a σ-bond metathesis cycle. 2.3 Catalysis at the Node via Transmetalation The postsynthetic exchange of a metal species on the node of a MOF can become unfavorable due to saturated coordination environments, challenging kinetic barriers, and/or diffusion limitations [35,87]. However, recent developments have overcome such difficulties to afford the rational design of frameworks. For example, a single crystal to single crystal metalation provides a route for an intermediate metal exchange process to access MOFs which are difficult to synthesize de novo. PCN-426-Mg was unreactive toward a direct metal exchange with CrIII [88]. However, the clever metalation of MgII with FeII in the framework, followed by air oxidation to form FeIII, formed PCN-426-Fe(III) that readily exchanges FeIII for CrIII to yield PCN-426-Cr(III). The highlighted examples of metal exchange within MOFs represent some synthetic strategies for the design of effective catalysts. First synthesized by Denysenko et al., the Zn-MFU-4l framework has been well-studied as a catalyst support due to its propensity to undergo facile transmetalation at the node [89]. Metal exchange was employed to target the rational design of a MOF node reminiscent of the highly active ethylene dimerization catalyst [TpMesNi]+ (TpMes = HB(3-mesitylpyrazolyl)3) that typically deactivates due to aggregation in solution [90]. Zn-MFU-4l underwent transmetalation to produce a series of Ni-MFU-4l MOFs with controlled amounts of exchanged Ni. The active site of Ni-MFU-4l was well-defined through single crystal studies (Fig. 11 A). While the parent MOF Zn-MFU-4l was inactive for alkene dimerization, optimal conditions for Ni-MFU-4l yielded a TOF as high as 41,500 h−1. Impressively, the metal exchanged MOF outperformed the benchmark homogenous [TpMesNi]+ complex that afforded 34,600 h−1 TOF. A systematic investigation of the effect of mass transport on ethylene consumed per mole of Ni indicated that the highest Ni exchange yielded the lowest TOF, rationalized with mass transport limitations. However, the optimized framework of Ni(1%)-MFU-4l was highly selective for producing butene (96%) and surpassed that of current industrial homogeneous complexes (87%) [91]. A Cossee-Arlman mechanism, consistent with faster chain transfer than chain propagation, favors a high formation of butene and was proposed as the catalytic cycle (Fig. 11B). Follow-up work with isotopic labeling, mechanistic probes, and DFT calculations further supported this pathway [92]. Ni(10%)-MFU-4l exhibited a modest decrease in activity over 72 h of continuous cycling experiments while the homogenous counterparts’ activity decreased by 50% over 1 h, permitting industrial viability of such a heterogeneous system. The versatility of the MFU-4l framework extends through transmetalation of ZnII with MnII, FeII, CoII, NiII, and CuII, whose corresponding MOFs are inaccessible through direct synthesis [93]. Liquid phase oxidation reactions of ethylbenzene with the MFU-4l family indicated that Co and Cu were highly selective toward the ketone product with modest conversions. Unlike the Co framework, an induction period of Cu-MFU-4l was observed for the system, yet both systems produced similar yields (Fig. 12 ). A delay in reaction time was attributed to a slow conversion of the co-catalyst N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) to phthalimide N-oxyl (PINO) radicals which initiate radical oxidation of CH bonds. However, upon removing Cu-MFU-4l from the reaction, the acetophenone yield increased typically indicative of catalyst leaching; however, comparable Zn/Cu ratios prior to and after catalysis point to minimal leaching. Additional insights into why Cu-MFU-4l experiences such induction and leaching phenomena which is not observed in Co-MFU-4l would be intriguing. The MnII and FeII frameworks readily oxidized to MnIII and FeIII preventing any oxidation of the substrate. 3 Catalysis at the linker Judicious linker selection can serve as a platform for spatially isolating active catalyst as struts in a MOF, often imparting stability otherwise inaccessible in solution. Functionality in the linker can either be achieved de novo [94] or accessed via a precursor and obtained postsynthetically [95]. MOF literature boasts a wide library of examples of effective linker engineering that have accomplished fundamental organic transformations such as olefin epoxidations [96,97] or Knoevenagel condensations [98,99]. Such early successes prompted the implementation of more sophisticated linkers into frameworks, such as chiral spacers or redox active groups, to attempt more challenging feats in asymmetric catalysis [100,101] and photocatalysis [102,103], respectively. We highlight select examples below in which isolating the struts at the linker outperforms homogenous substrates in solution or stabilizes new catalytic pathways altogether. The squaramide-based linker has been successfully incorporated into a UiO-67 type MOF to spatially isolate the linkers, which readily self-associate form hydrogen-bonding networks in solution [104]. Motivated by the hydrogen bond-donating abilities of the linker, the MOF successfully catalyzed a demanding Friedel-Crafts reaction between indole and β-nitrostyrene. The UiO-67 squaramide based MOF outperformed the catalytically inactive free squaramide moieties (Fig. 13 A). The pure squaramide based MOF achieved only a 22% yield due to low surface area from a reduction in pore accessibility with the bulky linker. To achieve a more sterically forgiving system, a mixed linker MOF comprised of equimolar biphenyldicarboxylic acid and squaramide linker (Fig. 13B) increased reaction yield to as high as 78%. Free-base porphyrin linkers in PCN-222/MOF-545 can be used for the selective oxidation of a sulfur mustard simulant, 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES), to yield the nontoxic 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfoxide (CEESO) (Fig. 14 A) [105]. Porphyrins are well known photosensitizers that generate 1O2 from ground state 3O2 under light irradiation, and the generated singlet oxygen serves as a reliable oxidant. Generation of 1O2 by PCN-222/MOF-545 was confirmed through singlet oxygen sensor green fluorescence. The selective oxidation of CEES with a half-life of 13 min was accomplished under O2 with blue LED (Fig. 14B). Lower wavelength white and red LEDs also demonstrated selective CEESO formation but in higher half-lives due to poorer spectral overlap with the Soret band. To further probe 1O2 generation, air was explored as the source of oxygen under blue LED to yield a half-life of 21 min. The scope of the above strategy was extended to the pyrene-containing NU-1000 which accomplished a half-life of 6.2 min (Fig. 14A/C) [106,107]. The isolation of pyrene in a MOF lattice outperformed the activity of free pyrene in solution which afforded a half-life of 10.5 min. Encouraging conversion of CEES prompted the detoxification of mustard gas (HD) by NU-1000. The slower half-life of 33 min for HD conversion was rationalized by poor solubility of HD. Efforts to install extended π-π systems in MOFs for photocatalytic properties have been hindered by the low solubility of such organic linkers that can impede MOF crystallization [108]. Recent work elegantly incorporated a hexabenzocoronene (HCHC) based linker into a Zr-based MOF, PCN-136, with a postsynthetic aromatization of the hexaphenylbenzene (HCBB) linker in parent MOF pbz-MOF-1 (Fig. 15A )[109]. Attempts to synthesize PCN-136 directly from the Zr6 node and the HCHC were unsuccessful. Both MOFs possess 6-connected pbz topology and likely go through a single crystal to single crystal transformation, which was determined through single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. PCN-136 outperformed pbz-MOF-1 in the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 over PCN-136 to produce HCCO− under visible light (Fig. 15B). In the presence of Ru(bpy)3Cl2 as a photosensitizer, pbz-MOF-1 achieved comparable results to PCN-136. The incorporation of the HCHC linker in PCN-136 prevented the self-association of such π-π systems that typically occur in solution to efficiently adsorb visible light and prevent rapid excited state quenching. Following the transfer of electrons to the Zr6 node, authors proposed a ZrIII active site reduces CO2 to HCOO− and regenerates the ZrIV species. 3.1 Catalysis at the linker via postsynthetic modifications A report by Lin and coworkers detailed the site-isolation of a solution inaccessible (bpy)Co(THF)2 species in the struts of bipyridyl- and phenanthryl-based linkers in UiO-type MOFs (Fig. 16) [110]. Such Co species usually undergo bimolecular decomposition to form coordinately saturated complexes or metal nanoparticles when used in solution. Characterized through single crystal analyses, the Co-loaded MOF catalysts were used in a variety of organic transformations including olefin hydrogenations, arene borylations, and the hydroboration of ketone and aldehydes. Using their mBPP-MOF-CoCl2 (Fig. 16), the work reported the highest turnover number (TON) to date of a Co-catalyzed olefin hydrogenation with 2.5 × 106 for the hydrogenation of 1-octene. A (bpy –)CoI(THF)2 species was predicted and characterized to undergo coordination to the targeted alkene and provided greater mechanistic insight to the highly reactive species. Despite being a highly effective organocatlyst, N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have not been sucessfully integrated into MOFs until recently [95,111]. Through postsynthetic ligand exchange with the parent MOF UiO-68-NH2, a pre-synthesized free NHC complex was incorporated into the framework (Fig. 17 ). The high porosity of UiO-68-NHC, 1H digestion analysis, and comparable inductively coupled plasma (ICP) ratios of ligand/Zr suggest that the NHC bearing ligand is incorproated as a linker rather than trapped in the pores. Using UiO-68-NHC, the hydrosilylation of CO2 with diphenylsilane was preformed to yield silyl methoxide (SMO). Followed by a mild hydrolysis, a nearly quantitative yield of methanol was achieved under mild conditions (1 atm CO2, RT). The NHC linker in solution, on the other hand, required harsh activaiton conditions and favored the formation of unwanted disiloxane (DSO). DFT studies suggested that increased DSO production in free NHC species results from a higher diffusion barrier of the larger substrate while the spatial isolation of NHC in a MOF reduces such a barrier. Therefore, DSO remained at NHC sites longer in solution and subsequently preform additional reactions that preclude a high yield of methanol. Alternatively, π-π interactions between SMO and the phenyl based linker in UiO-68-NHC favored a migration of the final SMO product to the MOF pores where they are less likely to undergo deleterious side reactions. This postsynthetic ligand exchange technique to synthesize previouly inaccesible MOFs has also been implemented in the synthesis of robust porphyrin MOFs (RPMs) [112], a family of microporous MOFs with two different metals incoporated into the porphyrin struts [113]. 4 Catalysis in cavity via encapsulated species MOFs can contain SSHCs beyond structural elements or adhered species; they can also exist within the MOF pores, trapped by noncovalent interactions [114–116]. Immobilization of typically homogenous catalysts on a stabilizing solid heterogeneous support, such as a MOF, can protect complexes from surrounding solvent or poisons and prevent species aggregation, the mechanism by which many catalysts become deactivated [117]. These composite materials are typically denoted [catalyst]@[support], when the catalyst is encapsulated within the support. Here, we highlight transition metal (TM) complexes, enzymes, and polyoxometalates (POMs) as typically homogeneous catalysts which have been installed in the pores of MOFs to alter stability and/or reactivity during organic transformation reactions [118]. 4.1 Catalysis at transition metal complexes in MOFs The accessibility of multiple stable oxidation states makes transition metal (TM)-based complexes good catalysts, which have been exploited by the chemical industry to assist in the creation of millions of tons of chemicals each year [119–122]. Because of the sensitivity of TM complexes, using homogenous TM-based catalysts often require milder conditions to operate optimally than their heterogeneous counterparts. As such, a number of ways to encapsulate transition metal catalysts have been discovered to access such reactivity with a stabilizing scaffold. One commonly used postsynthetic technique for the inclusion of encapsulated species in porous materials is through ion exchange, using an intrinsically charged support to allow for systematic replacement of counterions [123–127]. This synthetic tool, relying on van der Waals and electrostatic interactions, was used to encapsulate Crabtree’s catalyst [Ir(cod)(PCy3)(py)][PF6] (cod = 1,5-cyclooctadiene, Cy = cyclohexyl, py = pyridine) in Na+ salt of sulfonated MIL-101(Cr) to form [Ir]@MIL-101(Cr)-SO3 (Fig. 18 ) [123]. The commercially available Crabtree’s catalyst can perform hydrogenation and hydrogen-transfer reactions [128,129], but has a propensity to form inactive metal hydrides under catalytic conditions [130,131]. The sulfonated MIL-101(Cr) contains BDC linkers functionalized with Brønsted acidic sulfonate groups [132], whose acidic protons can be exchanged postsynthetically. In MIL-101(Cr)-SO3, approximately 7% of the sodium cations were exchanged with the Ir catalyst, equating to 2.28 wt%. Due to size restrictions, the maximum ion exchange efficiency was calculated to be 9%. In liquid phase hydrogenation reactions with a linear, unhindered alkene, the encapsulated species maintained similar catalytic activity when compared to the homogeneous catalyst. When the alkene was instead hindered or cyclic, the homogeneous complex outperformed the composite, likely owing to diffusion limitations engendered by the MOF support. This observation, however, indicates that the catalyst indeed was located within the pores of the MOF and not only on the surface, which is often difficult to differentiate. The dispersion of the Ir catalyst within the MOF allowed for superior performance in gas/solid hydrogenation conditions compared to the nonporous Ir catalyst alone. To exploit the hydrophilic nature of the sulfonate groups on the linker and the Lewis acidic Cr3+ nodes and Na+ ions, the hydrogenation of several olefinic alcohols was also tested, where hydrogenation and isomerization are competing pathways [133]. The encapsulated species was found to be resistant to deactivation during the reaction and more selective for the hydrogenation products compared to the Ir complex alone. The superiority of the [Ir]@MIL-101(Cr)-SO3 was attributed to not only the spatial separation of the active species preventing deactivation via self-association, but also the reversible coordination of the sulfonate favoring the hydrogenation reaction. The identity of the charged counterion species in the MOF (i.e. the node or the linker) used for ion exchange to encapsulate TM catalysts was explored by Sanford and coworkers (Fig. 19 ) [124]. As a complement to the ligand-centered charge in MIL-101-SO3, ZJU-28 is an anionic MOF, comprised of In3 nodes and BTB (4,4′,4″-benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(benzoate)) linkers with three [Me2NH2]+ counterions, where the charge is node-centered [134]. Using an anionic platform for cation exchange [135] circumvents the need to graft functional groups within the MOF [136]. Two cationic Rh complexes for catalytic alkene hydrogenation [137–140] were encapsulated in ZJU-28 and MIL-101-SO3. Both (dppe)Rh(cod)BF4 and (MeCN)2Rh(cod)BF4 (dppe = 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane) were incorporated similarly (3 and 2 wt%, respectively) in the two MOFs. The dppe-ligated MOF-supported complexes were able to catalyze the hydrogenation of 1-octene to n-octane and maintain catalytic performance through 5 cycles. The significantly faster conversion of Rh complexes in MIL-101-SO3 was in part attributed to the larger pores size compared to ZJU-28, where diffusion limitations more severely impacted catalysis. In addition to the choice of MOF scaffold, the ligands of the TM complex itself affect catalysis. The MeCN ligated Rh complex, when supported on both MOFs, suffered from low conversions under the same conditions used for the dppe-ligated analogue. Despite the fundamental correlation between charge location within a MOF and the resulting catalytic activity, further investigations to preclude diffusion limitations would be highly intriguing. Another postsynthetic technique of encapsulating species in MOFs is through “aperture opening” to intentionally create missing linker defects [141,142]. In protic solvent, linkers of a pre-formed MOF partially dissociate from the framework to open apertures previously blocked by linkers. The target sorbate is too large to fit through the apertures of the unmodified MOF; after loading the catalyst in protic solvent, excess linker is introduced back into the system, blocking the newly formed apertures. The TM@MOF can then be immersed in aprotic solvent to prevent linker dissociation and subsequent catalyst leaching. Thus, the identity of the solvents used is critical to the successful implementation of aperture opening/closing events [143–145]. This method was used to encapsulate the CO2 hydrogenation catalyst [146], ruthenium complex (tBuPNP)Ru(CO)-HCl (tBuPNP = 2,6-bis((di-tert-butyl-phosphino)methyl)pyridine) in UiO-66, resulting in the composite [Ru]@UiO-66 that was 0.35 wt% Ru catalyst (Fig. 20 ) [147]. By isolating the Ru complex within the MOF pores, bimolecular decomposition, the pathway through which the catalyst typically deactivates, was repressed as indicated through recyclability tests. The composite maintained activity over 5 cycles whereas the homogeneous catalyst severely suffered in activity after 1 cycle. The robustness of the composite materials was further tested against thiols, known poisons for the Ru catalyst [148,149]. Even using small molecule thiols, the composite activity outperformed that of the unencapsulated Ru catalyst. Further, the activity of the composite catalyst did not suffer in the presence of bulky thiols due to size exclusion, where the homogeneous reaction performed similarly in the presence of smaller thiols. The technique assumes that the encapsulated species is stable in protic solvents. 4.2 Catalysis at enzymes in MOFs Enzymes are nature’s machines, capable of performing specific tasks using environmentally accessible reagents like O2 and H2O. When taken out of their native environment, enzymes can suffer from aggregation and/or irreversible denaturation [150–152], limiting the extent to which enzymes can be stored, utilized, and recycled. To prevent these deactivation pathways, these biomolecules can be immobilized on solid supports [153–157]. Often, perturbations in structure during encapsulation/immobilization can affect the secondary structure of the enzyme, rendering the enzyme more or less active [158,159]. Here, we focus on those composites where the enzyme benefits from encapsulation. Encapsulation can occur during MOF formation with the addition of enzyme to the MOF mixture, and the MOF grows around the enzyme in a process termed biomimetic mineralization [160]. Due to their mild synthetic conditions, ZIFs have been widely explored for enzyme encapsulation via biomineralization or coprecipitation [161–165]. Enzymes such as catalase, however, are deactivated by encapsulation in the hydrophobic ZIF-8, likely owing to the strong hydrophobic interactions leading to denaturing and loss of activity. To investigate this effect, Doonan and coworkers have compared the activities for decomposition of H2O2 of catalase (CAT) in ZIF-8 to in hydrophilic ZIF-90 and MAF-7 (Fig. 21 A) [166]. The three MOFs possess the same Zn2+ in sodalite (sod) topology but contain different linkers. Specifically, ZIF-8 has 2-methylimidazolate linkers, ZIF-90 has 2-imidazolcarboxaldehyde linkers, and MAF-7 has 3-methyl-1,2,4-triazolate linkers. Electrostatic potential mapping shows that ZIF-90 can hydrogen bond at the aldehyde substituent, where MAF-7 can hydrogen bond at the annulet nitrogen not involved with node binding. In agreement with previous reports, CAT@ZIF-8 exhibited limited catalytic activity due to perturbations of the tertiary structure upon immobilization. CAT@ZIF-90, on the other hand, showed moderate activity, and CAT@MAF-7 performed comparably to free CAT (Fig. 21B). The MOF shell was then further examined to determine whether the MOF could protect the activity of the enzyme in inhospitable environments [167,168]. After treatment with heat, unfolding agents, proteolytic agents or organic solvents, the composite materials exhibited superior catalytic activity to the free enzyme, demonstrating that the MOF shell could indeed protect the enzyme from such environmental factors. A similar study by Tsung and coworkers found that ZIF-8, despite rendering catalase inactive, protected the structure under typically denaturing conditions [169]. The development of permanently mesoporous MOFs allowed for the postsynthetic encapsulation of large enzymes within MOFs, not just on the surface. As a result, Ma and coworkers capitalized on these large pore structures to encapsulate microperoxidase-11 (MP-11) in Tb-mesoMOF, [170] first reported by Choi et al. [171]. The MOF itself is composed of triazine-1,3,5-tribenzoate (TATB) linkers and TbIII nodes, giving rise to 3.9 and 4.7 nm cages (Fig. 22 A) that can accommodate the 3.3 × 1.7 × 1.1 nm enzyme [172]. MP-11@Tb-mesoMOF was investigated for the oxidation of 3,5-di-tert-butyl-catechol (Fig. 22B) [173,174]. The MOF composite performed superior to the free enzyme due to the aggregation of free MP-11 in solution. For comparison, MP-11 was also immobilized on mesoporous silica MCM-41. Interestingly, MP-11@Tb-mesoMOF displayed higher catalytic activity to the MP-11@MCM-41 (Fig. 22C), partially owing to the leaching of enzyme from the latter case. The stability of MP-11@Tb-mesoMOF was further investigated by Ma and coworkers through Raman spectroscopy [175] and later EPR [176]. Further adapting mesoporous MOFs for enzymatic catalysis applications, the NU-100x isoreticular series, composed of Zr6-nodes and pyrene-core linker, features the systematic expansion of interconnected hierarchical channel-type pores. This family was used to immobilize two enzymes which could work in tandem in a cell-free environment [177]. The 4,8-connected csq topology was previously determined to be ideal for the encapsulation of enzymes [178], as the larger pore could support the enzyme while the smaller channel provides an auxiliary path for substrate. These two channels are further connected through orthogonal apertures, allowing the substrate to access the active enzymes. Interestingly, the simple addition of phenylene spacers to extend the linker resulted in MOFs with 4,12-connected ftw topology instead; subtle changes in linker geometry and torsion angles can direct MOF crystallization toward one morphology over another [38,179–181]. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)@NU-100x was assayed in the catalytic conversion of pyruvate and lactate with concurrent NAD+ reduction to NADH (Fig. 23 A) [182]. Reactivity was found to increase with increasing pore size. However, the reactions with micron-sized crystallites of composites were much slower than with free enzyme. Thus, the reaction rates can be limited through not only the diffusion within the channels, but also diffusion through the crystallite itself. Indeed, when the particle size of LDH@NU-1005 was reduced from 2 μm to 400 nm, the reaction rate became comparable to that of free LDH. The system was further expanded to include diaphorase, regenerating NAD+ from NADH coupled to the reduction of resazurin to resoufin, to monitor the reaction by fluorescence (Fig. 23B) [183]. Each half reaction in the composite exhibited a slower performance than free LDH + diaphoarase. However, the presence of both enzymes in or on the MOF resulted in enhanced rates of the larger NU-100x (x = 5–7) frameworks as compared to free enzyme (Fig. 23C), likely due to the pre-concentration of substrate in the supported MOFs. 4.3 Catalysis at POMs POMs, like TM catalysts (vide supra), have a rich history in catalysis, owing to the reversible redox-active metal centers [184]. Composed of high-valent group V and VI transition metals connected via oxide bonds, POMs are well-defined, anionic clusters whose components can be substituted with nearly any element [185–187]. Their solubility, low surface area, and instability under catalytic conditions make heterogenizing POMs attractive for implications in long-term catalytic applications [188,189]. POM applications have largely focused on their utility in electrocatalysis and proton conduction [190–194], but they have also been used as catalysts in organic transformations, where the POM acts as an oxidation or a Brønsted/Lewis acid catalyst which will be highlighted here [195,196]. Additionally, this review will focus on encapsulation examples where the POMs are not structural components, as in polyoxometalate-open frameworks (POMOFs) [197–200]. Porous 3D MOFs can broadly be classified in two groups based on the size of the apertures relative to the pore size: cage-type, or channel-type; typically, cage-type MOFs are used to encapsulate POMs. The installation of POMs can be accomplished through building the MOF around the POM or installing POMs postsynthetically through a variety of methodologies. A systematic study of incorporating POMs in MOFs de novo reported the synthesis of the NENU-x (x = 1–6) series [201]. HKUST-1, also known as MOF-199 and Cu-BTC, was built around Keggin-type POMs ([H2SiW12O40]2−, [H2GeW12O40]2−, [HPW12O40]2−, [H2SiMo12O40]2−, [HPMo12O40]2−, [HAsMo12O40]2−; x = 1–6, respectively) with two tetramethylammonium (TMA) counterions from a one-step hydrothermal reaction. Due to the smaller size of the apertures compared to the POMs, the material was stable towards POM leaching and exceeded the loadings of most traditional POM-supported materials. This work provided one of the first crystal structures for these POM/MOF hybrid materials (Fig. 24 ) [202]. Since acidified [PW12O40]3- is known to be the strongest acid in the Keggin series [203,204], the TMA ions in NENU-3 were replaced with protons to yield NENU-3a, and titration experiments confirmed the retention of the POM’s acid properties in the MOF. These composites were used for the hydrolysis of ethyl acetate in water and compared to other acid catalysts. Normalized to the amount of acid, NENU-3a exhibited the highest activity among the solid oxides, organic resins, and liquid acids referenced by this study. Notably, NENU-3a exceeded the gravimetric activity of homogeneous H3PW12O40. As the size of the ester increased to include aromatic R groups, the diffusion of the substrate through the pores was hindered, resulting in lower catalytic activity of bulkier esters (Fig. 24). Other NENU series MOFs have since been used as acid catalysts [26,205,206]. Despite achieving good dispersion, stability, and recyclability, these studies highlight the diffusion limitation considerations within this class of materials. Postsynthetic incorporation of POMs into cage-type MOFs has primarily relied upon the mesoporous MIL MOF series; note, POMs can also be incorporated into the MIL series de novo. Férey and co-workers first demonstrated that a POM with ˜1 nm diameter could fit through the apertures of MIL-101(Cr) [66]. Since then, many groups have explored POM@MIL composites for catalytic applications [208–214]. Among the various studies, a sandwich-type POM ([Co4(PW9O34)2]10−) was encapsulated in MIL-101(Cr) postsynthetically, by adding the MOF to a POM solution [215]. The composite material was used for the oxidation of alkenes and alkanes (Fig. 25 ), which had been previously catalyzed by Co4(PW9)2 homogeneously [216]. For geraninol and limonene, Co4(PW9)2@MIL-101 obtained full conversion after 24 h using H2O2 as the oxidant (Fig. 25), whereas Co4(PW9)2 exhibited slightly faster activity. Oxidation of styrene occurred much quicker on Co4(PW9)2@MIL-101 than in the homogeneous reaction. While the composite had slightly lower activity in the oxidation of cyclooctane than the homogeneous POM, the composite reaction had higher selectivity. Further, the composite was able to be recycled with 17% leaching between cycles. Though not discussed, this material was shown to exhibit both diffusion and confinement effects using their substrate scope. POMs can also be encapsulated postsynthetically in channel-type MOFs, first accomplished with H3PW12O40 in NU-1000 [218]. Due to the strong electrostatic interaction between the POM and MOF, the composite (PW12@NU-1000) was stable to leaching. PW12@NU-1000 as-synthesized exhibited different intensities in the PXRD pattern than the same material heated to 120 °C. If the location of an electron-rich guest molecule is periodic, then the resulting composite X-ray diffraction pattern could be influenced. To further investigate this observation, differential envelope density (DED) analysis determined that the electron density associated with the PW12 clusters was located in the mesopores of PW12@NU-1000 after supercritical CO2 activation. This density shifted to the micropores upon heating the composite to 120 °C (Fig. 26A and B) [219]. The material activated at the two different temperatures was used as catalysts for the oxidation of 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES) using H2O2 as the oxidant (Fig. 26 C). While both PW12@NU-1000 materials exhibited enhanced rates compared to PW12 and NU-1000 alone, the supercritically activated sample was 3-fold faster than the same material activated at 120 °C (Fig. 26D). The rate enhancement was attributed to the greater accessibility of the POM active sites in the mesopores as compared to in the micropores. 5 Conclusions Atomic level knowledge of the uniform active sites present in SSHCs can realize precise structure-activity relationships for next-generation catalyst design that are rarely possible in other heterogeneous systems. Metal–organic frameworks offer the uniformity to support SSHCs. Through MOF’s versatility, a variety of methodologies can be employed to install SSHC at the framework node and linker or to encapsulate one within the cavity. Formative work stabilizing OMS within a MOF laid the foundation for using such sites to catalyze fundamental organic transformation and impressively, the destruction of chemical warfare agents. Appreciable development of postsynthetic metal deposition and exchange expanded the library of such frameworks to produce highly effective catalysts, including those that outperform current industrial standards for ethylene dimerization. Rational linker design or postsynthetic linker modification stabilizes attractive functionalities, such as NHC species or moieties with π-π interactions, which are typically solution inaccessible due to self-association. Deactivation via self-association for other typically soluble catalysts, as in TM complexes, enzymes, and POMs, can effectively be prevented through encapsulation and immobilization of such species in a MOF. Careful tuning of the MOF support’s properties (i.e. hydrophobicity, aperture size, location of charges) can impart increased catalytic efficiency with the composite material, while simultaneously protecting and stabilizing the encapsulated species from deactivating conditions. The highlighted works featured in this review capture a general overview of the pivotal early work through more recent approaches, and the studies identified in the following section illustrate the niche directions to further exploit the utility of MOFs as SSHCs. 6 Future outlook Isolating an active metal catalytic complex during MOF synthesis, rather than postsynthetically, can be a powerful tool to shortcut the precise introduction of an active site in the MOF. The synthesis of a Zr-based MOF linked by palladium aryl diphosphonite pincer complexes was achieved by Wade and coworkers via a one-pot reaction [220] equivalent homogenous Pd complexes in transfer hydrogenation of benzaldehyde. Future work developing similar MOF synthesis strategies with de novo introduction of sophisticated metallated linkers would greatly benefit the field. Utilizing Zr-based MOF-808 as the parent support by Yaghi, three models inspired by the copper oxygen active site in particulate methane monooxygenase enzyme (pMMO) were synthesized to selectively oxidize methane to methanol [221]. A series of postsynthetic modifications introduced imidazole species to serve as a support for the deposited copper-oxygen complexes, highlighting how MOFs provide a platform to sequentially build sophisticated catalysts. The rich topology offered by MOFs can precisely tune the proximity and position of desired anchoring sties to stabilize other biologically inspired active sites (Fig. 27 ). Recent advancements have enabled periodic installation of multiple single active sites in a MOF. For example, the postsynthetic metalation of a Cd-Cd bimetallic paddle-wheel, porphyrin-salen based MOF, ps-CMOF, can be accomplished with CuII, ZnII, NiII, and CoII [222]. The small ionic radii of these species are well-known to yield paddle-wheel MOFs [64,65,223–226]. Single crystal to single crystal transformations precisely confirmed the bimetallic paddle-wheel clusters obtained with postsynthetic transformation for the first time (Fig. 28 ). Additionally, the CuII and ZnII species metallated the free-base porphyrin despite two-fold interpenetration in the framework. The utilization of multiple single active sites within one entity to accomplish a cascading series of reactions has long intrigued researchers. Defined as two or more successive, independent reactions carried out in a one-pot fashion without need to purify intermediates, tandem catalysis has immediate implications in higher reaction efficiencies and greener chemistry aims [227,228]. Towards this goal, the one-pot tandem epoxidation and subsequent epoxide-ring work by Beyzavi et al was accomplished using the Fe@Hf-2 framework, composed of a Hf6 node with postsynthetic incorporation of 2 Fe on the node and an iron porphyrin linker [229]. Tandem catalysis within a MOF can also be achieved using immobilized species [230]. Catalysts anchored on 2D MOFs eliminate deleterious diffusion effects when encapsulated species occupy the same pores which the substrate must access. To this end, Co-linked TCPP(Fe) nanosheets were chosen to support glucose oxidase (GOD). The composite reaction catalyzed the conversion of glucose into gluconic acid and H2O2 at the enzyme; then the porphyrin moieties oxidized L-arginine to nitric oxide using the generated H2O2. A reversible installation and facile exchange between different spacer ligands in a parent Zr-based LIFM-28 MOF, termed dynamic spacer installation (DSI), generated four highly controlled multivariate MOFs [231]. DSI was coupled with postsynthetic modification processes to form either a single active site or multiple single sites capable of catalyzing useful organic transformations in tandem or stepwise fashion. In one case, a framework containing two spacers with either a deposited Cu(I) site or amine functionality facilitated the sequential oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Following the addition of malononitrile, a nearly quantitative yield of the Knoevenagel product was achieved without need to separate or purify the benzaldehyde intermediate. The development of DSI and similar strategies [232] is an encouraging step toward streamlining MOF catalytic processes and working toward green chemistry objectives. Lastly, we discuss advancements that motivate next-generation MOF-based SSHC design with further tuning. Efforts toward the design of chiral catalysis have been well-documented with a single chiral moiety installed in MOFs [101,233–235]. Impressive progress by Kutzscher et al. provides a single crystal analysis of a MOF containing six stereocenters [236]. The use of such a framework for highly enantioselective transformations that necessitate the presence of multiple stereocenters highlights another realm for implementing MOF catalysts. One-pot syntheses of mixed metal nodes on MOFs are intriguing for novel catalysts; however, the exact metal node structure is often unknown and difficult to determine. Recent advancements by Lomachenko, Lamberti, and collaborators detail the exact stoichiometry of mixed CeZr nodes through extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analyses [237]. However, further attention is needed to develop SSHCs of such mixed systems. Moreover, computational modeling of known SSHC MOF catalysts can probe mechanistic uncertainties or provide a high-throughput screening to predict better catalysts [238–241]. However, for both experimental and computational fields to work in tandem to their fullest potentials, exhaustive experimental characterization of the active site is critical to develop highly representative models. The initial scope of implementing MOFs as catalysts has dramatically expanded over the past decade to envision and realize the development of highly sophisticated SSHCs. Moving forward, the bottom up synthesis of more complex structures with multiple active sites on MOF supports is a powerful platform to access intricate, high commodity chemicals. To realize such systems, the field will greatly benefit from continued advancements of strategic synthetic approaches. With the fundamental understanding of SSHCs, we believe that MOF-supported SSHCs will become an advanced tool for the interrogation of current catalysts, the advancement of currently employed catalysts, and the implementation of multifunctional catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous catalysts streamline industrial processes due to high stability and ease of separation. Efforts toward predictive catalytic activity and rational design of next-generation systems are impeded by structural ambiguity stemming from the presence of multiple irregular active sites within a catalyst. The uniformity of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) provides a platform on which to develop single site catalysts in order to delineate atomically precise design rules. In this critical review, we highlight the development and progress of MOF-based single site catalysts and provide an outlook for further advancement of the field.
coredata.dc:title: Metal–organic frameworks: A tunable platform to access single-site heterogeneous catalysts
